com.google.android.agera

Interface Reservoir<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Observable, Receiver<T>, Repository<Result<T>>, Supplier<Result<T>>

    public interface Reservoir<T>
extends Receiver<T>, Repository<Result<T>>
    A buffering mechanism that enqueues the values received via the Receiver interface and offers them back through the Repository interface.

    Values can be enqueued using Receiver.accept(T). It is up to the implementation, typically the backing store, to decide whether and how to enqueue each value. Values are dequeued using Supplier.get(). This is a fallible operation (an attempt that returns a Result). Calling Supplier.get() when the reservoir is empty yields Result.absent().

    The Updatables observing this reservoir will be updated when a value is enqueued while the reservoir is empty, or when a value is dequeued so the next enqueued value is exposed, but not when the last value is dequeued so the reservoir becomes empty. In other words, an update from this reservoir means the availability of the next value to be dequeued. Additionally, when an updatable activates the reservoir, i.e. turns it from unobserved to observed, if it is already non-empty, the updatable will receive an out-of-band update immediately (subject to Looper processing delay). Subsequently added updatables will not receive this special call: it is assumed that the availability of the currently exposed value will have been notified to existing updatables, and that a consumer will dequeue the value soon.

    Multiple compiled repositories using the same reservoir as their shared event source and data source can be a simple way to achieve parallelism with load balancing.

    • Method Summary

      • Methods inherited from interface com.google.android.agera.Receiver

        accept

      • Methods inherited from interface com.google.android.agera.Observable

        addUpdatable, removeUpdatable

      • Methods inherited from interface com.google.android.agera.Supplier

        get
